front.title: Proof of Process: Succinct Evidence Aggregation Extension

abstract.t: This document defines an extension to the Proof of Process architecture that enables succinct aggregation of evidence records using Merkle tree structures and recursive proof systems. By leveraging Verifiable Delay Functions (VDFs), STARK proof composition, and Halo2 recursive circuits, Verifiers can efficiently validate large volumes of authorship evidence without processing each individual record. The aggregation mechanism preserves the temporal ordering guarantees of the base protocol while reducing verification complexity from linear to logarithmic.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Proof of Process (PoP) architecture defined in the base specification generates a continuous stream of evidence records during the creative authorship process. For long-duration works or prolific authors, the volume of evidence can grow to millions of individual records, making full verification impractical for many Relying Parties.

This document specifies a succinct aggregation extension that compresses arbitrarily large evidence chains into constant-size proofs. The extension operates at three levels: Merkle tree commitment of batched VDF outputs, STARK-based proof composition for cross-batch verification, and Halo2 recursive circuits for full-chain summarization.

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Merkle Tree Aggregation
section.t: Evidence records produced during a single authorship session are organized into a binary Merkle tree as defined in . Each leaf node contains the SHA-256 hash () of a serialized evidence record encoded in CBOR (). The Merkle root serves as a succinct commitment to the entire batch.

The Attester MUST construct the Merkle tree using the append-only property: new evidence records are added as rightmost leaves, and the tree is never rebalanced. This ensures that inclusion proofs for earlier records remain valid as new records are appended. Batch sizes SHOULD be powers of two to simplify proof generation.

Inclusion proofs allow a Verifier to confirm that a specific evidence record is part of a committed batch without downloading the entire batch. The proof consists of the sibling hashes along the path from the leaf to the root, requiring O(log n) hashes for a batch of n records.

section.title: Recursive Proof Composition
section.t: While Merkle trees provide efficient inclusion proofs within a single batch, verifying temporal ordering across batches still requires processing each batch root sequentially. This document defines a recursive proof composition scheme using STARK and Halo2 proof systems to eliminate this linear dependency.

A STARK proof attests to the correct computation of VDF outputs within a batch. The prover generates a STARK proof that the VDF chain from the first to the last record in a batch was computed correctly. Multiple STARK proofs are then composed using Halo2 recursive circuits, producing a single constant-size proof that covers an arbitrary number of batches.

The recursive proof MUST be signed using COSE_Sign1 () with the same Attester key used for individual evidence records. The payload of the COSE structure contains the Halo2 proof bytes, the first and last VDF outputs, and the total record count.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The aggregation mechanism introduces a trust dependency on the soundness of the underlying proof systems. If the STARK or Halo2 proof system is broken, an adversary could forge aggregated proofs without possessing the original evidence. Implementers SHOULD support multiple proof systems to allow migration.
